review.title: Stochastic blockmodel approximation of a graphon: Theory and consistent estimation
review.abstract: Non-parametric approaches for analyzing network data based on exchangeable graph models (ExGM) have recently gained interest. The key object that defines an ExGM is often referred to as a graphon. This non-parametric perspective on network modeling poses challenging questions on how to make inference on the graphon underlying observed network data. In this paper, we propose a computationally efficient procedure to estimate a graphon from a set of observed networks generated from it. This procedure is based on a stochastic blockmodel approximation (SBA) of the graphon. We show that, by approximating the graphon with a stochastic block model, the graphon can be consistently estimated, that is, the estimation error vanishes as the size of the graph approaches infinity.
histories: 20 pages, 4 figures, 2 algorithms. Neural Information Processing Systems, 2013
20 pages, 4 figures, 2 algorithms. Neural Information Processing Systems (NIPS), 2013
review.COMMENTS: 20 pages, 4 figures, 2 algorithms. Neural Information Processing Systems, 2013

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: From the well-known Small World network to the latest large-scale data collected by online service providers such as Wikipedia, Twitter and Facebook, there is always a dynamic in the search for better and more informative representations of graphics (Fienberg et al. 1985; Nowicki and Snijders 2001a; Hoff et al. 2002; Handcock et al. 2007; Airoldi et al. 2008; Xu et al. 2012; Azari and Airoldi 2012; Goldenberg et al. 2009; Kolaczyk et al. 2009; Kolaczyk et al. 2011; Zhao et al. 2011; Orbanz et al. 2013).The root of the non-parametric model is found in the community (Bickel et al. 2009; Lloyd et al. 2012; Bickel et al. 2011; Zhao et al. 2011; Orbanz et al. 2013).

sections.heading: 2 Stochastic blockmodel approximation: Procedure
sections.text: In this section, we present the proposed SBA algorithm and discuss its basic properties.

sections.heading: 2.1 Assumptions on graphons
sections.text: We assume that w is piecemeal, i.e. there is a sequence of non-overlapping intervals Ik = [αk − 1, αk], defined by 0 = α0 <. < αK = 1, and a constant L > 0, so that for any (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) ĂIij = Ii · Ij, | w (x1, y1) − w (x2, y2) | ≤ L (| x1 − x2 | + | y1 − y2 |). Generally, we assume that w is asymmetric, i.e., w (u, v) 6 = w (v, u), so that symmetric graphs can be considered a special case. Consequently, a random graph generated by w is directed, i.e. G [i, j] 6 = G [j, i].

sections.heading: 2.2 Similarity of graphon slices
sections.text: The intuition of the proposed SBA algorithm is that if the graph is smooth, adjacent cross-sections of the graph should be similar. In other words, if two labels (Ui, Ui) and the labels (Ui, Uj) are close, then the difference between the labels (Ui, Ui) and the labels (Ui, Ui) should be small. To measure the similarity between two labels, we define the following labels (Ui, Ui, Ui).

sections.heading: 2.3 Blocking the vertices
sections.text: The similarity metric d,.., G2T discussed above suggests a simple method of estimating w by a piecemeal constant function w,.. (i.e., a stochastic block model). Since the blocks B,.., G2T are defined, we can group the (unknown) designations {u1,.., un} intoK blocks B,.., B, K using a procedure described below. Once the blocks B,..., B,., K are defined, we can then determine w,. (ui, uj.) by calculating the empirical frequency of the edges between blocks B,. i and B,.

sections.heading: 2.4 Main algorithm
sections.text: Algorithm 1 Stochastic Block Model ApproximationInput: A series of observed graphs G1,...., G2T and the precision parameter ∆. Output: Estimated stochastic blocks B-1,..., B-K. sections.heading: 3 Stochastic blockmodel approximation: Theory of estimation
sections.text: In this section we will present the theoretical aspects of the proposed SBA algorithm. We will first discuss the properties of the estimator d ыij and then show the consistency of the estimated diagram w т. Details of the proofs can be found in the supplementary material.

sections.heading: 3.2 Choosing the number of blocks
sections.text: The performance of algorithm 1 is sensitive to the number of blocks it defines. On the one hand, it is desirable to have more blocks so that the graph can be finely approximated, but on the other hand, if the number of blocks is too large, each block will contain only a few large blocks, which is bad because estimating the value on each block requires a sufficient number of nodes in each block. Trade-off between these two cases is controlled by the precision parameter: a large block generates few large blocks, while small blocks generate many small clusters. A precise relationship between K and K, the number of blocks generating the algorithm, is given in Theorem 2.Theorem 2.Theorem 2.Theorem, and K is the number of blocks estimated by Algorithm 1, while small blocks generate many small clusters.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the proposed SBA algorithm based on some empirical results. For comparison, we consider (i) the universal singular value threshold (USVT) (Chatterjee); (ii) the largest gap algorithm (LG) (Channarond et al. 2012); (iii) matrix completion from a few entries (OptSpace) (Keshavan et al. 2010).

sections.heading: 4.1 Estimating stochastic blockmodels
sections.text: Accuracy as a function of increasing graph size. Our first experiment is to evaluate the proposed SBA algorithm for estimating stochastic block models. To this end, we generate (arbitrarily) a graph = 0.8 0.9 0.4 0.5 0.1 0.6 0.3 0.3 0.2 0.8 0.3 0.4 0.2 0.9, (12), which creates a piecemeal constant function with 4 x 4 common space.Since USVT and LG use only one observed graph, while the proposed SBA requires at least 2 observations, to make the comparison fair, we use half of the nodes for SBA by generating two independent n2 · n2 observed graphs. For USVT and LG, we use an n · n observed graph. Figure 2 (a) shows the asymptotic behavior of the algorithms when n grows. Figure 2 (b) shows the estimation error of the SBA algorithm, since T for graph 200 of the number of increasing universe precision = a growing universe.

sections.heading: 4.2 Estimation with missing edges
sections.text: Our next experiment is to evaluate the performance of the proposed SBA algorithm if there are missing edges in the observed diagram. To model missing edges, we construct a n · n binary matrix M with the probability Pr [M [i, j] = 0] = 0, where 0 ≤ в ≤ 1 defines the percentage of missing edges. As 2T matrices with missing edges are created and the observed diagrams are defined as M1 х G1, the modification of the proposed SBA algorithm for missing links is minimal: the calculation (6) refers to elementary multiplication, the aim being to investigate how well SBA can reconstruct the graph w and in the presence of missing links.

sections.heading: 4.3 Estimating continuous graphons
sections.text: Our final experiment is the evaluation of the proposed SBA algorithm in the estimation of continuous graphs. Here, we consider two of the graphs reported in (Chatterjee): w1 (u, v) = 11 + exp {− 50 (u2 + v2)} and w2 (u, v) = uv, where u, v [0, 1]. At this point, w2 can be considered a special case of the eigenmodel (Hoff 2008) or latent feature relative model (Miller et al. 2009). Results in Figure 4 show that while both algorithms have improved estimates when n grows, performance depends on which of w1 and w2 we examine. This suggests that in practice the choice of algorithm should depend on the expected structure of the graph to be estimated: if the graph generated by the graph exhibits some low-grade properties, then USVT is probably a better option. For more structured or complex graphs, the proposed method is recommended.

sections.heading: 5 Concluding remarks
sections.text: The proposed algorithm approaches the continuous graph through a stochastic block model, in which the first step is to group the unknown vertex markers by empirically estimating the distance between two graph sections to blocks, and the second step is to create an empirical histogram to estimate the graph. A complete consistency analysis of the algorithm is derived, the algorithm has been evaluated experimentally, and we found that the algorithm is effective in estimating block-structured graphs. Code. An implementation of the stochastic block model approximation algorithm (SBA) proposed in this paper is available online at: https: / / github.com / airoldilab / SBAAcknowledgments. The EMA is partially supported by the NSF CAREER award IIS-1149662, ARO MURI Prize W911NF-11-1 0036.

In this paper, we develop a new computational tool to study one type of non-parametric representations which recently draws significant attentions from the community (Bickel and Chen 2009; Lloyd et al. 2012; Bickel et al. 2011; Zhao et al. 2011; Orbanz and Roy 2013).

In this paper, we develop a new computational tool to study one type of non-parametric representations which recently draws significant attentions from the community (Bickel and Chen 2009; Lloyd et al. 2012; Bickel et al. 2011; Zhao et al. 2011; Orbanz and Roy 2013).

In this paper, we develop a new computational tool to study one type of non-parametric representations which recently draws significant attentions from the community (Bickel and Chen 2009; Lloyd et al. 2012; Bickel et al. 2011; Zhao et al. 2011; Orbanz and Roy 2013).

The root of the non-parametric model discussed in this paper is in the theory of exchangeable random arrays (Aldous 1981; Hoover 1979; Kallenberg 1989), and it is presented in (Diaconis and Janson 2008) as a link connecting de Finetti’s work on partial exchangeability and graph limits (Lovász and Szegedy 2006; Borgs et al. 2006).

(Lloyd et al. 2012) proposed a Bayesian estimator without a consistency proof; Choi and Wolfe (Choi and Wolfe) studied the consistency properties, but did not provide algorithms to estimate the graphon.

The proposed method is called the Stochastic blockmodel approximation (SBA) algorithm, as the idea of using a two-dimensional step function for approximation is equivalent to using the stochastic block models (Choi et al. 2012; Nowicki and Snijders 2001a; Hoff 2008; Channarond et al. 2012; Rohe et al. 2011).

The proposed method is called the Stochastic blockmodel approximation (SBA) algorithm, as the idea of using a two-dimensional step function for approximation is equivalent to using the stochastic block models (Choi et al. 2012; Nowicki and Snijders 2001a; Hoff 2008; Channarond et al. 2012; Rohe et al. 2011).

For the purpose of comparison, we consider (i) the universal singular value thresholding (USVT) (Chatterjee); (ii) the largest-gap algorithm (LG) (Channarond et al. 2012); (iii) matrix completion from few entries (OptSpace) (Keshavan et al.
2012); (iii) matrix completion from few entries (OptSpace) (Keshavan et al. 2010).
For the fairness of the amount of data that can be used, we use n2 × n2 × 2 observations for SBA, and n × n × 1 observation for USVT (Chatterjee) and LG (Channarond et al. 2012).
Here, we use 2× 2×2 observations for SBA, and n×n×1 observation for USVT (Chatterjee) and LG (Channarond et al. 2012).
Here, w2 can be considered as a special case of the Eigenmodel (Hoff 2008) or latent feature relational model (Miller et al. 2009).

metadata.abstractText: Non-parametric approaches for analyzing network data based on exchangeable graph models (ExGM) have recently gained interest. The key object that defines an ExGM is often referred to as a graphon. This non-parametric perspective on network modeling poses challenging questions on how to make inference on the graphon underlying observed network data. In this paper, we propose a computationally efficient procedure to estimate a graphon from a set of observed networks generated from it. This procedure is based on a stochastic blockmodel approximation (SBA) of the graphon. We show that, by approximating the graphon with a stochastic block model, the graphon can be consistently estimated, that is, the estimation error vanishes as the size of the graph approaches infinity.
